intro: Allium splendens subsp. prokhanovii, commonly known as the Armenian leek, is a perennial bulbous plant native to the Caucasus region. It features narrow, grass-like leaves and produces clusters of pale purple to white flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm and prefers well-drained, loamy soils. It is adapted to temperate climates and is often found in mountainous areas. Its bulbs are edible and have a mild, onion-like flavor, making it a valuable crop in local cuisines.
